title: American Airlines cabin attendant 'may have exposed passengers to Hepatitis A on several flights'
text:
Passengers travelling on an American Airlines flight may have been exposed to Hepatitis A by a flight attendant.

A member of the cabin crew suffered diarrhea on several flights in September, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

As a result 18 passengers on board a flight from San Francisco to Charlotte, North Carolina, on September 21 were given vaccinations.

American Airlines is also notifying crew from other flights the infected employee was on board, according to local media.

There is no immediate threat of a widespread outbreak of the highly infectious disease, health officials said.

An American Airlines plane at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport on Monday (file image). The airline contacted 18 passengers to warn them about a Hepatitis A infected employee

The CDC was notified on October 1 that a male attendant on flight AA1960 had a confirmed case of Acute Hepatitis A (HAV) infection, according to The Charlotte Observer.

In a statement, the airline said that it's in 'close contact' with public health officials over the incident, as well as the CDC.

Crystal Byrd a spokeswoman for American Airlines said: 'The safety of our customers and team members is our top priority.

'We are in close contact with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and public health officials and will coordinate with them on any required health and safety related measures.'

Rebecca Carter, Mecklenburg County Public Health Department spokeswoman, said county health officials spoke on the phone with the 18 passengers from the Charlotte area who were on the flight.

The Heptitis A virus (above a 3D illustration) is highly contagious and can cause fatigue, low appetite, stomach pain and nausea but can be prevented with a vaccine

She added: 'The risk was only to the passengers on the flight, there was no risk to the public.'

Hepatitis A is a highly contagious, but 'vaccine-preventable' disease of the liver caused by the hepatitis A virus, according to the CDC.

Symptoms include fatigue, low appetite, stomach pain, nausea and jaundice.

'It is usually transmitted person-to-person through the fecal-oral route or consumption of contaminated food or water,' the CDC website states.

Mecklenburg County is already in the midst of what federal health officials described as a Hepatitis A outbreak.

Between April 2018 and June, 39 cases in the county were reported, including 12 this year.

Cases across the US have risen nationally since 2012, according to official figures.
description: A member of American Airlines' cabin crew who was infected with Hepatitis A suffered from diarrhea on several flights in September. As a result 18 passengers on a flight to Charlotte were vaccinated.
